[[File:Plan carthage romaine.jpg|thumb|Plan of Roman Carthage]] [[File:Karta Karthago.PNG|thumb|Map of Roman remains within the modern [[Carthage municipality]].]] [[Image:Ruines de Carthage.jpg|thumb|Antonine baths ruins, from the Roman period]] After the destruction of [[Ancient Carthage|Punic Carthage]] in 146 BC, a new city of [[Carthage]] ([[Latin]] ''[[:wikt:Carthago#Latin|Carthāgō]]'') was built on the same land. By the 3rd century, Carthage developed into one of the largest cities of the [[Roman Empire]], with a population of several hundred thousand.<ref name=cities>Likely the fourth city in terms of population during the imperial period, following [[Rome]], [[Alexandria]] and [[Antioch]], in the 4th century also surpassed by [[Constantinople]]; also of comparable size were [[Ephesus]], [[Smyrna]] and [[Pergamum]]. Stanley D. Brunn, Maureen Hays-Mitchell, Donald J. Zeigler (eds.), ''Cities of the World: World Regional Urban Development'', Rowman & Littlefield, 2012, [https://books.google.ch/books?id=0mQ4tc5QpQcC&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 27]</ref> It was the center of the Roman province of [[Africa Province, Roman Empire|Africa]], which was a major breadbasket of the empire. Carthage briefly became the capital of a usurper, [[Domitius Alexander]], in 308–311. Conquered by the [[Vandals]] in 439,<ref>[https://books.google.be/books?id=_Jntu21N9K0C&pg=PA402 p.402]</ref> Carthage served as the capital of the [[Vandal Kingdom]] for a century. Re-conquered into the [[Byzantine Empire under the Justinian dynasty|Byzantine Empire]] in 533/4, it continued to serve as a Roman (Byzantine) regional center, as the seat of the [[praetorian prefecture of Africa]] (after 590 the [[Exarchate of Carthage]]) until it was finally destroyed in the [[Muslim conquest of the Maghreb]] in 698.
==Foundation== [[Image:Roman-Villas-Carthage.jpg|thumb|Roman villas, Carthage]] By 122 BC, [[Gaius Gracchus]] founded a short-lived [[Colonia (Roman)|colony]], called ''[[Colonia Junonia|Colonia Iunonia]]'', after the Latin name for the Punic goddess [[Tanit]], ''Iuno Caelestis''. The purpose was to obtain arable lands for impoverished farmers. The [[Roman Senate|Senate]] abolished the colony some time later to undermine Gracchus' power.
After this ill-fated attempt, a new city of Carthage was built on the same land by [[Julius Caesar]] in the period from 49 to 44 BC, and by the first century, it had grown to be the fourth largest city of the empire, with a population in excess of 100,000 people.<ref name=cities/> It was the center of the [[Africa (Roman province)|province of Africa]], which was a major breadbasket of the Empire. Among its major monuments was an [[Carthage amphitheatre|amphitheater]], built in the 1st century, with a capacity of 30,000 seats.
==Early Christianity== Carthage also became a center of [[early Christianity]]. [[Tertullian]] rhetorically addressed the Roman governor with the fact that the Christians of Carthage that just yesterday were few in number, now "have filled every place among you —cities, islands, fortresses, towns, market-places, the very camp, tribes, companies, palaces, senate, forum; we have left nothing to you but the temples of your gods." (''[[Apologeticus]]'' written at Carthage, c. 197).
In the first of a string of rather poorly reported [[Councils of Carthage|Councils at Carthage]] a few years later, no fewer than 70 bishops attended. Tertullian later broke with the mainstream that was represented more and more by the bishop of Rome, but a more serious rift among Christians was the [[Donatist]] controversy, which [[Augustine of Hippo]] spent much time and parchment arguing against. In 397 at the [[Council of Carthage (397)|Council of Carthage]], the [[Biblical canon]] for the western Church was confirmed.
==Vandal period== The [[Vandals]] under their king [[Genseric]] crossed to Africa in 429,<ref>Collins, Roger (2000), "Vandal Africa, 429–533", XIV, Cambridge University Press, pp. 124</ref> either as a request of [[Bonifacius]], a Roman general and the governor of the [[Diocese of Africa]],<ref>Procopius Wars 3.5.23–24 in Collins 2004, p. 124</ref> or as migrants in search of safety. They subsequently fought against the Roman forces there and by 435{{cn|date=August 2018}} had defeated the Roman forces in Africa and established the [[Vandal Kingdom]]. Genseric was considered a heretic, too, an [[Arianism|Arian]], and though Arians commonly despised [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] Christians, a mere promise of toleration might have caused the city's population to accept him.
==Byzantine period== {{see|Exarchate of Carthage|Carthage (episcopal see)}} After a failed attempt to recapture the city in the 5th century, the Byzantines finally subdued the Vandals in the [[Vandalic War]] of 533–534. Using Gaiseric's grandson's deposal by a distant cousin, [[Gelimer]], as either a valid justification or pretext, the Byzantines dispatched an army to conquer the Vandal kingdom. On Sunday, October 15, 533, the Byzantine general [[Belisarius]], accompanied by his wife [[Antonina (wife of Belisarius)|Antonina]], made his formal entry into Carthage, sparing it a sack and a massacre.
Thereafter, the city became the seat of the [[praetorian prefecture of Africa]], which was made into an [[exarchate]] during the emperor [[Maurice (emperor)|Maurice's]] reign, as was [[Ravenna]] on the Italian Peninsula. These two exarchates were the western bulwarks of the Roman Empire, all that remained of its power in the West. In the early seventh century, the exarch of Carthage overthrew the Roman emperor, [[Phocas]].
==Islamic conquest== The Exarchate of Carthage was first assaulted by the [[Muslim conquest of the Maghreb|Muslim expansion]] initiated from [[Egypt]] in 647, without lasting effect. A more protracted campaign lasted from 670 to 683. In 698, the [[Exarchate of Africa]] was finally overrun by Hassan Ibn al Numan and a force of 40,000 men. Carthage was destroyed and its population was displaced to the neighboring [[medina of Tunis]], which became the major regional center. Carthage's materials were used to supply the expansion of Tunis.<ref>http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/97373/Carthage</ref> The destruction of the Exarchate of Africa marked a permanent end to the Byzantine Empire's influence in the region.

'''Berwick Run for The Diamonds''' is a nine-mile [[foot race]] starting and ending on Market Street in downtown [[Berwick, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Footracing in Berwick">{{cite book |last=Will-Weber |first=Mark |title=Run for the Diamonds, 100 Years of Footracing in Berwick, Pennsylvania |year=2008 |url=http://www.runfordiamonds.com/book.html |accessdate=17 April 2013|isbn=978-1891369780}}</ref> It has been held every year on [[Thanksgiving Day (United States)|Thanksgiving Day]] since 1908.<ref>[https://arrs.run/HP_Berw9.htm Run for the Diamonds 9 Mile]. [[Association of Road Racing Statisticians]] (2011-11-28). Retrieved 2011-12-18.</ref>
The first race had only 13 participants. The course has remained essentially unchanged since 1908, running up a very challenging hill and through the countryside of [[Summer Hill, Pennsylvania|Summerhill]]. No women competed officially until 1972 when two women ran. The one hundredth running of the annual event was held in 2009. It was canceled twice due to [[World War I]] in 1918 and 1919.
The race was called the "Berwick Marathon" until the 1970s and 1980s. But since the race is too short to qualify as a [[marathon]], and winners receive diamonds as part of their prize, the name was changed to "Run for the Diamonds".
The number of participants has grown dramatically, from about 100 runners in 1973 to 1,985 runners in 2009. The course record of {{abbr|43:21|43 minutes and 21 seconds}} was set in 1980 by [[Pete Pfitzinger]].
==Course== The race starts on Market Street in Berwick and goes north along that street for about a mile before turning onto Summerhill Road, which becomes Foundryville Road as it goes through the municipality of [[Foundryville, Pennsylvania|Foundryville]]. After passing through Foundryville around mile 2, it goes up a very long and steep hill known as "The Hill". After cresting the hill around mile 3.5, it heads mostly downhill to the halfway point where it turns onto Kachinka Hollow Road and continues descending to Martzville Road at mile 7. The course follows Martzville Road back to Market Street, and then after a mile on Market Street.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://maps.google.com |title=Google Maps |year=2012 |accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref> However, from 1946 to 1954, the race finished at [[Crispin Field]] in Berwick.<ref name="Footracing in Berwick"/>

'''[http://scinema.australiascience.tv/ The SCINEMA International Science Film Festival]''' is an Australian [[film festival]] celebrating international science-related drama and documentary films. The festival was founded with the aim of forging links between the sciences and the arts.<ref name=scin>{{cite web |url=http://www.scinema.com.au/aboutus/index.html |title=Scinema - About Us |accessdate=2008-10-07 |publisher=scinema.com.au |date=28 July 2008 }}</ref> SCINEMA accepts entries from all over the world. It is a program of [https://www.australiascience.tv/ Australia's Science Channel], operated by The [[Royal Institution of Australia]].
== Background == Founded in 2000 by Rebecca Scott and Damian Harris, the first festival played only in [[Canberra]] (at the Center Cinema) and was well attended, with some sold-out performances. Originally hosted by [[CSIRO]], the festival grew steadily over the 2000s.
After a brief hiatus (there was no festival in 2014-15), SCINEMA found a new home with the [[Royal Institution of Australia]]. The 2016 Festival received over 1,300 submissions from over 80 countries,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cosmosmagazine.com/society/film-festival-showcases-the-best-of-scientific-filmmaking|title=Film festival showcases the best of scientific filmmaking|website=Cosmos Magazine|access-date=2016-08-18}}</ref> and premiered in cities around Australia on 18 June 2016. The festival also hosts a community screening program as part of [[National Science Week]], where community groups and schools can register to run their own screening program. In 2016 over 240 events were held around Australia, with a screening even held on the [[Davis Station]] in Antarctica.
In 2017, over 37,000 people participated in the festival which was screened at 317 events around Australia. One reviewer said of the festival "The most noticeable thing about the films is that, collectively and individually, they are less explicitly about science and more about us. These are very human stories about how we engage with the world — with the things in it, and with each other."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://theconversation.com/film-festival-reveals-the-passion-emotion-and-disappointment-that-can-come-with-science-78393|title=Film festival reveals the passion, emotion and disappointment that can come with science|last=Ellerton|first=Peter|work=The Conversation|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en}}</ref>

Please don't edit this again without a discussion on "Talk" page (above, left), section "Years active"|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Stefan Raab | image = Stefan Raab-2.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = Stefan Raab at a [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]] press conference | birth_name = Stefan Konrad Raab | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1966|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Cologne]], [[West Germany]] | occupation = Entertainer, television host, comedian, musician, executive producer | years_active = 1990–2015
1998–present as executive producer | religion = | website = [http://www.tvtotal.de/ www.tvtotal.de] | height = | parents = | siblings = }} '''Stefan Konrad Raab''' (born 20 October 1966) is a German entertainer, comedian, musician and former television host. Raab began his television career hosting the comedy show ''[[Vivasion]]'' in 1993. He became well known in 1994 after composing a hit single spoofing national football coach [[Berti Vogts]]. From 1999 to 2015, he hosted the [[late-night talk show|late-night]] comedy show ''[[TV total]]'' and has also created a number of other television shows, such as ''[[Schlag den Raab]]'' and ''[[Bundesvision Song Contest]]''. In the early 2010s, Raab was considered the "most powerful man in German entertainment television".{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-76862428.html|title=Die Geiseln des Metzgers|publisher=''[[Spiegel online]]''|date=14 February 2011|accessdate=8 May 2011|language=German}} Raab is also known for his recurring role as producer, writer and performer of German entries to the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] beginning in 1998. He was the initiator of the national pre-selection show [[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010|Unser Star für Oslo]] (Our Star for Oslo), in which [[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Germany's winning entry]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010|2010 contest]] in Oslo was determined. ==Early life and family== Raab grew up in [[Cologne]] with his sister and his parents, who owned a butchers shop. He attended [[Jesuit]] boarding school [[Aloisiuskolleg]] in Bonn. Before entering the entertainment business, he worked as a butcher in his parents' shop and studied [[law school|law]] before dropping-out of university after five semesters. Raab lives in a suburb of Cologne and has two daughters (born 2004 and 2006) with his girlfriend Nike.{{Cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article152925/Stefan_Raab_wird_zum_zweiten_Mal_Vater.html|title=Stefan Raab wird zum zweiten Mal Vater|publisher=''[[Die Welt]]''|date=15 September 2006|accessdate=30 March 2010|language=German}} Other than this, very little is known about Raab, who deliberately hides his private life from the media. ==Career== === Television === Stefan Raab became popular as host of the comedy show ''Vivasion'' for the German [[music television]] channel [[Viva (TV station)|VIVA]] from 1993 to 1998. In 1999, he created ''TV total'' which began airing in April 2001 on [[ProSieben]], four times a week. While ''TV total'' started as a comedy format mainly showing and satirizing funny and embarrassing sequences from other television programs, it soon came to be more of a late night show featuring musical performances-- in some ways similar to ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' or ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''.[http://tvtotal.prosieben.de/tvtotal/infos/stefan/04176.html Stefan Raab biography]. {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126110351/http://tvtotal.prosieben.de/tvtotal/infos/stefan/04176.html|date=2013-11-26}} tvtotal.de. Accessed 30 March 2010. {{de icon}} After a [[boxing]] match against [[Regina Halmich]] in 2001 (rematch 2007) and a [[speed skating]] race against [[Claudia Pechstein]] in 2002, he also created several other celebrity sports events that are produced regularly, including ''TV total Turmspringen'' ([[high diving]]) and ''TV total Stock Car Crash Challenge'' ([[stock car racing]]). He also brought fun and variety to the show by invented new sports: In November 2003, he initiated the first "official" World [[Wok racing]] Championship in [[Winterberg]], Germany. Modified Chinese woks are used to make timed runs down an Olympic bobsled track. The championship has taken place every year since, most recently in March 2011 in [[Innsbruck]]. The first ''Autoball EM'', autoball being a version of football played in cars and using an [[exercise ball]] to score goals was made in 2007. In 2006, Raab invented the game show ''[[Schlag den Raab]]'' (German for ''Beat the Raab'', remade for British television as [[Beat the Star]] and as "Beat your ''host''" in several other European countries), in which he competes against a contestant in various disciplines – some episodes of the show lasted more than five hours with excellent quotas. Raab frequently organizes ''PokerStars.de Nacht'', a poker event featuring some celebrity names in German entertainment. In September 2012, he announced that he will be hosting a new talk show on [[ProSieben]] which will include political guests and begin airing on 11 November 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/tv/stefan-raab-moderator-plant-neue-talkshow-gegen-guenther-jauch-a-854750.html |title=Stefan Raab: Moderator plant neue Talkshow gegen Guenther Jauch |publisher=spiegel.de |language=German |date=9 September 2012}} It will stand in direct competition with the self-titled talk show hosted by [[Günther Jauch]]. In September 2013 Raab was one of four hosts (one from each big television network) at the federal election debate between chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] and her challenger [[Peer Steinbrück]]. In mid-2015, Raab announced his retirement from television and stated that he would remain hosting until the end of the year.{{cite web |url=http://www.tz.de/tv/stefan-raab-beendet-seine-tv-karriere-ende-jahres-zr-5121761.html |title=Stefan Raab beendet seine TV-Karriere zum Ende des Jahres |publisher=TZ |date=2015-08-28 |accessdate=2015-12-16}} The last episode of his show ''TV total'' aired on 16 December and the last episode of ''[[Schlag den Raab]]'' aired on 19 December 2015. ===Music=== [[File:Opening act 2, ESC 2011.jpg|right|thumb|Raab performing [[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Satellite]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011]] ]] Raab began working as a freelance producer and composer of jingles and radio commercials in 1990 at his own studio in Cologne.[http://www.laut.de/Stefan-Raab Stefan Raab biography]. laut.de. Accessed 30 March 2010. {{de icon}} From 1994 onwards, he produced a number of popular songs, including "Böörti Böörti Vogts" (a song about [[Berti Vogts]]), "Hier kommt die Maus" ("Here comes the mouse", a tribute to the children's television series [[Die Sendung mit der Maus]]), "[[Maschendrahtzaun]]", "Wir kiffen", "Gebt das Hanf frei!" ("Legalise Dope!", featuring [[Shaggy (artist)|Shaggy]] and samples from German politician [[Hans-Christian Ströbele]]), "Hol' mir ma' 'ne Flasche Bier" ("Get me a bottle o' beer", containing samples from then-Chancellor [[Gerhard Schröder]]), and "Space Taxi" from the soundtrack of the movie [[Traumschiff Surprise - Periode 1]].[http://www.mtv.de/music/184852-stefan-raab/bio Stefan Raab biography]. mtv.de. Accessed 30 March 2010. {{de icon}} He wrote the song for the German entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998]], [[Guildo Horn]]'s "[[Guildo hat euch lieb!]]",[http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-country/country?country=9 Germany country profile at eurovision.tv]. eurovision.tv. Accessed 30 March 2010. and in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2000]] he took part himself, performing the [[nonsense]] song "[[Wadde hadde dudde da?]]". Raab cast the German entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004 Eurovision Song Contest]] in a talent show contest called ''SSDSGPS'' ("Stefan sucht den Super-Grand-Prix-Star", "Stefan seeks the super Grand-Prix star", satirising the title of the German [[Idol series]] [[Deutschland sucht den Superstar]], ''DSDS'').[http://brainpool.tv/bpo/en/presse/pressemitteilungen/index_20040320_16722.html Max goes to Istanbul!]. brainpool.tv. Accessed 30 March 2010. The winner, [[Maximilian Mutzke]], came in eighth place. Bored with the Eurovision Song Contest, Raab came up with the [[Bundesvision Song Contest]] in 2005 (''Bundes''republik Deutschland = Federal Republic of Germany). The contest features representatives from each of the 16 [[states of Germany]] and stipulates that their song has to be at least partly in German. In 2009, Raab was approached by the public broadcaster [[Norddeutscher Rundfunk|NDR]], a member of the [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] broadcasting consortium, to jointly organise a national preselection in order to determine the German entry for the Eurovision Song Contest 2010. It was revealed that Raab initially refused the request, but that his television network ProSieben accepted the offer to work with ARD/NDR.Solloso, Jaime. [http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5867 Germany prepares for 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527163355/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5867 |date=27 May 2009 }}. oikotimes.com. 25 May 2009. Accessed 30 March 2010. As a result of the cooperation, the talent show contest Unser Star für Oslo (''Our Star for Oslo'') took place from 2 February 2010 onwards, stretching across 8 shows. Raab took a lead role in the programmes as head of the jury. In the national final on 12 March 2010, [[Lena Meyer-Landrut]] emerged as winner.Brey, Marco. [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=10293&_t=Lena+Meyer-Landrut+gets+German+ticket+to+Oslo Lena Meyer-Landrut gets German ticket to Oslo]. eurovision.tv. 12 March 2010. Accessed 30 March 2010. On 29 May 2010, Meyer-Landrut won the Eurovision Song Contest 2010 with the song "[[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Satellite]]", claiming the first German Eurovision victory in 28 years.Schacht, Andreas. [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18063&_t=GERMANY+WINS%2C+SEE+FULL+RESULTS! Germany wins: See full results]. Eurovision.tv. 30 May 2010. Accessed 30 May 2010. As a musician, Raab is an [[autodidact]], playing various instruments, such as piano, drums, guitar, [[ukulele]], and some wind instruments.Schüle, Christian. [http://www.zeit.de/2007/11/Portraet-Stefan-Raab Fernsehen: Das Prinzip Blamage]. zeit.de. 12 March 2007. Accessed 14 April 2010. {{de icon}} ====Participation at the Eurovision Song Contest==== {| class="wikitable sortable zebra" style="text-align:center" |- ! Year ! Place of Event ! Artist ! Song ! '''Host''' | 10 | 107 |} On 19 May 2011 Raab eventually ended his Eurovision involvement as a host, chairman of the jury, composer and musical producer.http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=36603&_t=stefan_raab_ends_eurovision_career ==Awards== For his television show [[Vivasion]] Raab received the ''Goldener Löwe'' (Golden Lion), the predecessor to ''[[Deutscher Fernsehpreis]]'' (German Television Award), in 1996. For ''[[TV total]]'' he received the ''Deutscher Fernsehpreis'' in 1999 as well as the comedy award ''[[Rose d'or]]'' in 2001. For his talent show ''SSDSGPS'' he was awarded the ''[[Adolf-Grimme-Preis]]'' in 2005 in for the "discovery and support of young music talents". On 29 May 2005, Stefan Raab received the ''Deutsch-Türkischer Freundschaftspreis'' (German-Turkish Friendship Award) for his TV total specials from [[Istanbul]] in preparation for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]]. He won the ''[[Bravo Otto]]'' in the category "Comedystar" from 2000 to 2003. In 2000 and 2005 Raab was awarded the ''[[Echo (music award)|ECHO]]'' (German music award) as "Best National Producer". In 2005 he also received the ECHO award as "media partner of the year"). On 29 September 2007, Raab received the ''Deutscher Fernsehpreis'' for "best entertainment show" for the fifth episode of ''[[Schlag den Raab]]''. On 6 February 2008 the show was awarded the ''[[Goldene Kamera]]'' (Golden Camera). Furthermore, Raab received the media award ''Bambi'' on 27 November 2008.[http://www.bambi.de/flash/#press,pressreleases,-,pressrelease,101 Stefan Raab bekommt BAMBI] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127135739/http://www.bambi.de/flash/ |date=27 January 2010 }}. Auf: bambi.de. In 2009 Raab won the ''Herbert Award 2009'' for ''best television sports show'' with the ''TV total Turmspringen''.[http://www.herbert-award.de/bin/ergebnisse_herbert-award_2009.pdf Ergebnisse des „Herbert-Award 2009“] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719040118/http://www.herbert-award.de/bin/ergebnisse_herbert-award_2009.pdf |date=19 July 2011 }}. Auf: herbert-award.de. [[Madame Tussauds]] in Berlin displays a [[wax figure]] of Stefan Raab since April 2009.''Madame Tussauds Berlin'' Website: [http://www.madametussauds.com/Berlin/UeberUns/Presse/Presseinformationen/StefanRaab/Default.aspx Presseinformation zur Ausstellung von Raabs Wachsfigur], 7 April 2009. Accessed 27 April 2009. As the initiator and president of the jury of the show ''[[Unser Star für Oslo]]'' he was awarded the ''[[Bayerischer Fernsehpreis]]'' (Bavarian television award) in 2010. On 12 November 2011, Stefan Raab came second in Synchronised diving, teaming with ''[[Elton_(comedian)|Elton]]'' in Munich, at the TV Total Turmspringen 2011 event. This was his first ever podium along with Elton at this event. ==Controversies== Raab has been the subject of [[lawsuit]]s throughout his career, some of which have gained public attention. The two most referenced cases are: *The case of then 16-year-old model Lisa Loch, who was ridiculed during some shows through Raab's assertion that her name ("Loch" meaning "hole" in German) made her more likely to find a job as an actress in [[pornographic movie]]s. Loch claimed she received anonymous obscene telephone calls, was mocked by classmates and in public and as a result suffered sleeplessness and was afraid to leave her home. A court in [[Hamm]] ordered Raab to pay €70,000 in compensation due to infringement of personal rights.[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,284903,00.html Raab zu 70.000 Euro Schadenersatz verurteilt]. spiegel.de. 4 February 2004. Accessed 30 March 2010. {{de icon}} *In an episode broadcast on 6 September 2004, Raab showed a clip, originally destined for a news broadcast, of a 28-year-old [[Turkish people|Turkish]] mother Nil S. holding a [[Schultüte]] (a cardboard cone, typically full of sweets, traditionally given to children in Germany on their first school day). Raab's comment, "Unbelievable! The [[drug trafficker]]s are disguising themselves better and better" ("eine Tüte" also means "a [[marijuana joint]]" in German slang, hence the pun), resulted in repeated lawsuits, and after a [[Munich]] court ruled against Raab, Nil S. settled for €20,000 compensation accompanied by a written apology.[http://www.stern.de/lifestyle/leute/beleidigungsklage-raab-spart-130000-euro-557968.html?q=Stefan+Raab Raab spart 130.000 Euro]. stern.de. 20 March 2006. Accessed 30 March 2010. {{de icon}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} * {{IMDb name|0704634}} * [http://www.tvtotal.de/ Official TV total website] {{de icon}} {{s-start}} {{s-ach}} {{Succession box| before=[[Sürpriz]]

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=There are large sections of the article that are uncited, which may indicate [[WP:OR|original research]].|date=December 2016}} {{refimprove|date=December 2016}} }} {{Infobox military conflict| |conflict = Tampico Affair |date = April 9, 1914 |place = [[Tampico, Tamaulipas|Tampico]], [[Tamaulipas]], [[Mexico]] |result = [[United States occupation of Veracruz|United States occupies Veracruz]] |combatant1 = {{flag|United States|1912}} |combatant2 = {{flagicon|Mexico|1893}} [[Mexico]] |strength1 = 9 [[sailor]]s |strength2 = ~10 [[infantry]] |casualties1 = |casualties2 = }} {{Campaignbox Battles of the Mexican Revolution involving the United States}} {{History of Mexico |1864-1928}} The '''Tampico Affair''' began as a minor incident involving [[United States|U.S.]] sailors and [[Mexican Armed Forces|Mexican]] land forces loyal to Mexican dictatorhttp://www.jornada.unam.mx/2015/01/02/estados/024n1est [[General]] [[Victoriano Huerta]] during the ''guerra de las facciones'' (faction wars) phase of the [[Mexican Revolution]]. A misunderstanding occurred on April 9, 1914, but developed into a breakdown of diplomatic relations between the two countries. As a result, the United States invaded the port city of [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]], [[United States occupation of Veracruz|occupying it for more than six months]]. This contributed to the fall of President [[Victoriano Huerta]], who resigned in July 1914. In the midst of the Mexican Revolution, ''[[de facto]]'' President Huerta struggled to defend his power and territory from the forces of [[Emiliano Zapata]] in the state of Morelos and the rapid advance of the Northern opposition [[Constitutionalists in the Mexican Revolution|Constitutionalists]] under the leadership of [[Venustiano Carranza]]. By March 26, 1914, Carranza's forces were {{convert|10|mi|km|abbr = on}} from the prosperous coastal oil town of [[Tampico, Tamaulipas]]. There was a considerable settlement of U.S. citizens in the area due to the immense investment by U.S. firms in the local oil industry. Several U.S. Navy warships commanded by [[Rear Admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] [[Henry T. Mayo]] were deployed off the coast for the stated purpose of protecting American citizens and property.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} The U.S. occupation of Veracruz resulted in widespread [[anti-Americanism|anti-American sentiment]] among Mexican residents, and other U.S. warships were used to evacuate U.S. nationals from both the Gulf Coast and the west coast of Mexico, taking them to refugee centers in [[San Diego]], California; [[Texas City, Texas|Texas City]], Texas; and [[New Orleans]]. As a result of anti-American sentiment, Mexico maintained neutrality during World War I, refusing to support the U.S. in Europe, all the while continuing to do business with Germany. With the U.S. threatening to invade in 1918 to take control of Tampico oil fields, Mexican President [[Venustiano Carranza]] threatened to have them destroyed to prevent their falling under U.S. control. == Background == By the spring of 1914, diplomatic relations between the US and Mexico were strained. [[US President]] [[Woodrow Wilson]] refused to recognize the presidency of Mexican General [[Victoriano Huerta]], who had been installed as president the previous year after Huerta and the conservative rebel [[Félix Díaz (politician)|General Félix Díaz]], a nephew of [[Porfirio Díaz]], had signed the Embassy Pact with the approval of US Ambassador [[Henry Lane Wilson]], who had since been removed by the president.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanforeignrelations.com/O-W/Wilsonian-Missionary-Diplomacy-Intervention-in-mexico.html|title=''Wilsonian Missionary Diplomacy- Intervention in Mexico''|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2014}} The instability caused by the ongoing [[Mexican Revolution]] threatened US lives and economic interests in Mexico. Although [[Tampico]] was besieged by Constitutionalist forces, relations between the US forces and Huerta's federal garrison remained amicable. The [[gunboat]] {{USS|Dolphin|PG-24|2}}, one of the few [[US Navy]] vessels able to sail up the [[Pánuco River]] through the shallow harbor entrance, had followed a request of the Mexican government to present a [[21-gun salute]] to the Mexican flag three times on April 2, 1914,Logbook of USS Dolphin to pay tribute to the celebrated occupation of [[Puebla, Puebla|Puebla]] in 1867 by Mexican General [[Porfirio Díaz]] in the last phases of the war to expel the forces supporting the [[French intervention in Mexico]]. [[File:Tampico_Incident.jpg|left|thumb|220x220px|US battleships steaming toward Veracruz following the Tampico Affair.
'''Inset:''' Appearing in the photograph (left to right): Rear Admiral Henry T. Mayo, Commander of U.S. forces during the Tampico Affair; Rear Admiral [[Frank Friday Fletcher|Frank F. Fletcher]], who commanded the landing to seize Veracruz; Vice Admiral [[Charles Johnston Badger|Charles J. Badger]], Commander of U.S. Atlantic Fleet in 1914.]] Relations between the US and Huerta deteriorated on April 9, when Mexican soldiers detained nine US sailors in [[Tampico]]. The commander of the ''Dolphin'' had tasked a purser and eight sailors with the purchase and pickup of urgently-needed 440 gallons of gasoline fuel from a dealer located near a tense defensive position at Iturbide Bridge that was held by Huerta's forces.{{cite book|last = Lenz|first = Lawrence|title = Power and Policy: America's First Steps to Superpower 1889-1922|date = 2008|publisher = Algora Publishing|location = New York|isbn = 0875866638|page = 186}} The defenders of the bridge anticipated an attack after skirmishes with Constitutionalist forces on the two preceding days. Nine US sailors on a [[whaleboat]] flying the [[US flag]] were dispatched to the warehouse along a canal. According to the sailors' account, seven of them were moving the cans of fuel (either 5-gallon or 55-gallon drums?) to the boat while two remained on the boat. Mexican federal soldiers were alerted to the activity and confronted the American sailors. Neither side could speak the other's language, and the sailors were not complying with commands from the soldiers. The Mexicans raised their rifles to the Americans, including the sailors still on the boat, and forcibly escorted them to the police headquarters for questioning. Although the sailors had been released after only a few minutes, Rear Admiral [[Henry T. Mayo]], the commander of U.S. naval forces in the area, demanded a 21-gun salute and a formal apology from Huerta's government. Mexican President refused to have his forces raise the US flag on Mexican soil to provide a 21-gun salute. Two weeks later, negotiations were at a standstill whe President Wilson asked the [[US Congress]] for permission for an armed invasion of the area. Although the request was granted two days later, the US had already begun to occupy Veracruz. [[File:U.S. Navy Destroyers at Mazatlan, Mexico, April 26, 1914.jpg|right|thumb|250x250px|USS ''Truxtun'' and ''Whipple'' at Mazatlan, April 26, 1914, keeping watch on Mexican gunboat ''Morales'' (two-funnel ship in background)]] ==Occupation of Veracruz== President Wilson backed Mayo and ordered an increase in US forces in Mexican waters. On April 18, {{USS|Iris|1885|6}}, Lieutenant [[Allen B. Reed]], commanding, tender for the [[United States Pacific Fleet|Pacific Fleet]] [[First Torpedo Flotilla]], {{USS|Cheyenne|BM-10|6}}, [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lieutenant]] [[Kenneth Heron]], commanding, tender for the Pacific Fleet [[Second Torpedo Flotilla]] and submarines {{USS|H-1|SS-28|6}} and {{USS|H-2|SS-29|6}} departed [[San Pedro, California]] for San Diego.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1914-04-18/ed-1/seq-10/;words=Iris+Cheyenne?date1=1912&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=Cheyenne+Iris&y=9&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=3|title=The Washington Times, April 18, 1914|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2014}} On April 22, ''Iris'' and five torpedo boats {{USS|Whipple|DD-15}}, {{USS|Paul Jones|DD-10}}, {{USS|Perry|DD-11}}, {{USS|Stewart|DD-13}} and {{USS|Truxtun|DD-14}}, of the Pacific Fleet [[First Torpedo Flotilla]], [[Lieutenant Commander]] [[Edwin H. Dodd]], commanding, departed San Diego for Mazatlan.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1914-04-23/ed-1/seq-3/%3bwords=tender+Iris?date1=1914&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1914&proxtext=tender+iris&y=12&x=14&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=2|title= More Battleships Ordered to Mexico |date= 23 April 1914 |publisher= ''The New York Sun''|accessdate=27 November 2014}}{{failed verification|date=December 2016}} On April 22, President Wilson received the backing of Congress for the use of military force to resolve the conflict with Huerta. The day before, he had ordered the Navy to seize the port of Veracruz, which was preparing to receive a German ship, the [[SS Ypiranga]], with an important cargo of ammunition intended for Huerta's troops. The message was relayed to Rear Admiral [[Frank Friday Fletcher]], who commanded the squadron lying off the port of Veracruz. With the battleships {{USS|Florida|BB-30|}}, {{USS|Utah|BB-31|}} and the transport {{USS|Prairie|AD-5|}} carrying 350 Marines, Fletcher received his orders at 8:00 AM on April 21. With impending poor weather conditions, Fletcher moved swiftly and requested for the US consul, William W. Canada, notify the local Mexican commander, General [[Gustavo Maass]], that Fletcher's landing parties would be taking control of the Veracruz waterfront. After sending some 200 soldiers to present a token defense, General Maass received orders from Mexico City to evacuate his troops to the nearby towns of Tejería and Soledad. Mexican legislators criticized the US, and mobs burned the US flag and looted US businesses in Mexico City. Just before 11:00 AM, a US landing party of 500 Marines and 300 sailors, commanded by Captain [[William R. Rush]] of USS ''Florida'', went ashore. Meeting no resistance, the Americans landed at Pier 4 and moved toward their objectives. The navy's [[sailors]] advanced to take the customs house, post and telegraph offices, and railroad terminal while the Marines were to capture the rail yard, the cable office, and the power plant. Establishing his headquarters in the Terminal Hotel, Rush sent a semaphore unit to the roof to open communications with Fletcher. While Maass retreated with his troops, the Mexican midshipmen at the Naval Academy worked to fortify their building. Fighting began when local policeman Aurelio Monffort fired on the Americans. He was killed by return fire, but his action resulted in widespread, disorganized fighting. Believing that a large Mexican force was in the city, Rush signaled for reinforcements and USS ''Utah'' sent its landing party ashore. Seeking to avoid further deaths, Fletcher asked Consul Canada to proxy a truce with the Mexican authorities. That effort failed when no Mexican leaders could be located. With the likelihood of further casualties from deeper incursion into Veracruz, Fletcher ordered Rush to hold his position and remain on the defensive through the night. During the night of April 21–22, additional US warships arrived, bringing reinforcements. That night, Fletcher determined that the complete occupation of Veracruz was necessary. He sent additional Marines and sailors ashore to begin landing around 4:00 a.m., and at 8:30 a.m., Rush resumed his advance, with ships in the harbor (USS San Francisco, USS Chester and USS Prairie), providing gunfire support. Striking near Avenida de Independencia, the Marines assaulted from structure to structure to neutralize resistance from the Huerta forces. On their left, the 2nd Seaman Regiment, led by {{USS|New Hampshire|BB-25|}} Captain [[Edwin A. Anderson]], made its way up Calle Francisco Canal. Even though the Mexican midshipmen had evacuated their school the previous evening, some Mexican civilians had taken defensive positions inside the building. Relying on incorrect information that his advance had been cleared of snipers, Anderson both failed to send out scouts and marched his men in parade ground formation. They encountered withering fire from the Mexicans and numerous casualties, forcing them to retreat. With supporting naval gunfire, Anderson resumed the attack and seized the Naval Academy and Artillery Barracks. Additional US force landed in the morning, and by noon, the US had taken much of the city. In the fighting, 19 Americans were killed and 72 wounded. Mexican losses were estimated at 150 to 170 soldiers killed and between 195 and 250 wounded; an unknown number of civilians were killed.Alan McPherson (2013) [https://books.google.com/books?id=utC5YT7wFgAC&q=%22unknown+number+of+civilians%22#v=snippet&q=%22unknown%20number%20of%20civilians%22&f=false ''Encyclopedia of U.S. Military Interventions in Latin America''], p. 393, ABC-CLIO, U.S.Susan Vollmer (2007) [https://books.google.com/books?id=UpnYYWaXLaAC&q=%22unknown+number+of+civilians%22#v=snippet&q=%22unknown%20number%20of%20civilians%22&f=false ''Legends, Leaders, Legacies''], p. 79, Biography & Autobiography, U.S. Mexican snipers were active until April 24, when Fletcher declared martial law. On April 30, the [[US Army]]'s 5th Reinforced Brigade, under Brigadier General [[Frederick Funston]], arrived and took over the occupation of the city. While many of the Marines remained, the naval units returned to their ships. While some in the United States called for a full invasion of Mexico, President Wilson limited American involvement to the occupation of Veracruz. Meanwhile, on the Pacific Coast of Mexico, US Naval units were monitoring the fight between Huerta's forces and the rebels while they proteced US citizens and interests. In [[Ensenada, Baja California]], US Consul [[Claude E. Guyant]] and 250 of his fellow citizens were forced to seek safety in the US consulate building, as Mexican authorities were powerless to control anti-American demonstrations that had erupted on April 23. Guyant cabled Washington, "Have taken refuge in consulate. Situation critical. Send warship immediately."{{cite news|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1914-04-24/ed-2/seq-4/;words=Guyant?date1=1912&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=Guyant&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=0|title= Blind with Anger Huerta Allowed Mobs to Riot in Mexico|first=William G.|last=Shepherd| date= 24 April 1914|work= [[The Day Book]]|location=Chicago|at=Image 4 |accessdate=27 November 2014}} USS ''Cheyenne'' was sent from [[San Diego, California]], to Ensenada with orders to protect US lives at any cost, including capturing the port if necessary. USS ''Iris,'' en route to Mazatlan, diverted course to Ensenada to assist ''Cheyenne''. They were to evacuate Guyant and other Americans.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1914-04-25/ed-1/seq-1/;words=Iris+torpedo?date1=1912&sort=relevance&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=%22IRIS%22+torpedo&y=9&x=13&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2&page=1&index=18|title= New Appeal from Ensenada |date= 25 April 1914 |publisher=''The New York Sun''|accessdate=27 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1914-04-25/ed-1/seq-12/;words=Mazatlan+Iris?date1=1912&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=Iris+mazatlan&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=4|title=Army and Navy Orders |date= 24 April 1914|publisher='' The Washington Times''|accessdate=27 November 2014}} The welfare of approximately 50,000 US citizens living in Mexico was affected by the invasion of Veracruz. Refugee camps were set up in San Diego, Texas, and New Orleans to receive the Americans.John Whiteclay Chambers & Fred Anderson (1999) [https://books.google.com/books?id=_Rzy_yNMKbcC&q=%22anti-North+American+riots%22#v=snippet&q=%22anti-North%20American%20riots%22&f=false ''The Oxford Companion to American Military History''], p. 432, Oxford University Press, England.Michael Small (2009) [https://books.google.com/books?id=KFgNYgx2rpEC&q=%22anti-american+riots%22#v=onepage&q=%22anti-american%20riots%22&f=false ''The Forgotten Peace: Mediation at Niagara Falls, 1914''], p. 35, University of Ottawa, Canada. Ultimately, the US military transport ship USS ''[[USAT Buford|Buford]]'' sailed from San Francisco in early May 1912,{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} and made stops at numerous ports on the west coast of Mexico to pick up additional American refugees. USS ''[[USS Iris (1885)|Iris]]'' also picked up numerous American refugees during May 1914, including Clement Edwards, the US consul at [[Acapulco]].{{cite web |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1912-04-28/ed-1/seq-1/;words=Guyant?date1=1912&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=Guyant&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=8 |title= Rescue Party Off for West Coast Monday |date= 28 April 1914 |publisher= ''The Bisbee Daily Review'' (Arizona) |accessdate= 27 November 2014 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141210045700/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1912-04-28/ed-1/seq-1/ |archivedate= 10 December 2014 |df= }} By May 4, 1914, a total of 71 US Navy ships were operating in Mexican waters.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1914-05-04/ed-1/seq-2/;words=Iris+Cheyenne?date1=1912&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=&date2=1915&proxtext=Cheyenne+Iris&y=9&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=1| title=71 US Warships Operating in Mexico |date= 4 May 1914|publisher= ''El Paso Herald''|accessdate=27 November 2014}} Battling rebel forces, Huerta was not able to mount a military opposition to the US occupation. After Huerta's downfall in July 1914, the US began discussions with the new government of [[Venustiano Carranza]], but its forces remained in Veracruz for seven months, until November 23. That was almost six months after the end of the [[Niagara Falls peace conference]], organized by the [[ABC countries]] (Argentina, Brazil, and Chile), held in the [[British Dominion of Canada]]. ==Legacy== The occupation contributed to Huerta's resignation in August 1914, as his southern armies' supplies ran out. In addition, the Tampico incident had later repercussions, as relations between the two countries were poor for a long time. In January 1917, Germany sent the so-called [[Zimmermann Telegram]], which implied that a Mexican alliance with Germany against the US would result in Mexico regaining territory taken from it by the US in prior wars and that Germany's forthcoming [[unrestricted submarine warfare]] campaign would guarantee defeat of the British and French. The British interception of Zimmermann's telegram and the German unrestricted submarine warfare against US merchant ships, soon afterward, were effectively both final justifications that President Wilson needed to request a [[American entry into World War I|declaration of war against Germany]], in April 1917.{{cite book |ref = Andrew|last = Andrew|first = Christopher|title = For The President's Eyes Only|year = 1996|publisher = Harper Collins|isbn = 0-00-638071-9}} Anti-American sentiment in Mexico from the Tampico incident was the chief reason that the government kept [[Mexico in World War I|Mexico neutral in World War I]].Lee Stacy (2002) [https://books.google.com/books?id=84krAQAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22mexican+neutrality%22 ''Mexico and the United States,'' Volume 3], p. 869, Marshall Cavendish, U.S. Mexico refused to participate with the US military excursion in Europe and granted full guaranties to German companies for keeping their operations open, specifically in Mexico City.Jürgen Buchenau (2004) [https://books.google.com/books?id=zj47Ky6ciJEC&q=%22mexican+neutrality%22#v=snippet&q=%22mexican%20neutrality%22&f=false ''Tools of Progress: A German Merchant Family in Mexico City, 1865-present''], p. 82, UNM Press, U.S. President Wilson considered another military invasion of Veracruz and Tampico in 1917–1918,Ernest Gruening (1968) [https://books.google.com/books?id=VoBlAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=occupation+president+wilson ''Mexico and Its Heritage''], p. 596, Greenwood Press, U.S.Drew Philip Halevy (2000) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=WOfKxFigGSwC Threats of Intervention: U. S.-Mexican Relations, 1917-1923]'', p. 41, iUniverse, U.S. to take control of the [[Isthmus of Tehuantepec]] and the Tampico oil fields.Lorenzo Meyer (1977) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PAy1AAAAIAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lansing+tehuantepec Mexico and the United States in the oil controversy, 1917-1942]'', p. 45, University of Texas Press, U.S. The relatively-new Mexican president, [[Venustiano Carranza]], threatened to destroy the oil fields in case the Marines landed there.Stephen Haber, Noel Maurer, Armando Razo (2003) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=znZ8Y8lO7_4C&q=+%22burning+of+the+oil+fields%22#v=snippet&q=%22burning%20of%20the%20oil%20fields%22&f=false The Politics of Property Rights: Political Instability, Credible Commitments, and Economic Growth in Mexico, 1876-1929''], p. 201, Cambridge University Press, UK.Lorenzo Meyer (1977) [https://books.google.com/books?id=PAy1AAAAIAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=destroy+fields ''Mexico and the United States in the Oil Controversy, 1917–1942''], p. 44, University of Texas Press, U.S. {{clear}} == See also == * [[Mexico in World War I]] * [[United States involvement in the Mexican Revolution]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.firstworldwar.com/atoz/tampico.htm Wilson "exasperated by... the latest in a line of Mexican incidents"] * [http://www.multied.com/documents/Tampico.html Wilson's address to Congress] (20 April 1914) [[Category:History of the foreign relations of the United States]] [[Category:1914 in Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican Revolution]] [[Category:Mexico–United States relations]] [[Category:Banana Wars]] [[Category:Political scandals in Mexico]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:April 1914 events]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1914]]

{{Infobox music festival | name =Tansen Samaroh | image =Tansen Samaroha.jpeg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | genre = | dates =4 days December | location =[[Gwalior]] district, [[Madhya Pradesh]] | years_active =1950s-present | founders = | attendance = | capacity = | website = }} '''Tansen Samaroh''' or '''Tansen Sangeet Samaroh''' ({{Lang-hi| तानसेन समारोह}}) is celebrated every year in the month of December in Behat village of [[Gwalior]] district, [[Madhya Pradesh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.festivalsofindia.in/tansen_samaroh/ |title=Tansen Sangeet Samaroh, Tansen Music Festival, Tansen Sangeet Samaroh 2012 |publisher=Festivalsofindia.in |date=2012-12-03 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref> It is a 4-day musical extravaganza . Artist and music lovers from all over the world gather here to pay tribute to the Great Indian Musical Maestro [[Tansen]]. The event is organized near the tomb of [[Tansen]] by the Academy of the department of culture, [[Government of Madhya Pradesh]].<ref>is being organised by the Academy of the department of culture in MP</ref> Artists from all over India are invited to deliver vocal and instrumental performances.
== National Music festival == Tansen Samaroh was originally a local festival but it was at the initiative of BV Keskar (1903 – 28 August 1984), who was Union Minister for Information and Broadcasting between 1952 and 1962, that Tansen Samaroh was turned into a popular national music festival.<ref>[[Anant Maral Shastri#Saluting the Legends]]</ref>
==Tansen Samman== The prestigious 'National Tansen Samman' is a musical award conferred to the exponents<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mpculture.in/html/Tansen%20Samman.pdf | title=Tansen Award winners | publisher=Madhya Pradesh Government | accessdate=12 October 2014 | author=Madhya Pradesh Government}}</ref> of [[Hindustani music]].
===Awardees=== [[File:Lokesh Anand performing at Tansen samaroh (Gwalior).jpg|thumb|Lokesh Anand performing at Tansen samaroh (Gwalior)]] * 2000 - [[Abdul Halim Jaffer Khan|Ustad Abdul Haleem Jafar Khan]]<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/2000/11/26/stories/1426212a.htm | title='Tansen Samman' for sitar maestro | date=25 Nov 2000 | agency=The Hindu | accessdate=12 October 2014 | author=Staff Correspondent | location=Bhopal}}</ref> - [[Sitar]] maestro. * 2001 - [[Amjad Ali Khan|Ustad Amjad Ali Khan]] - [[Sarod]] maestro. * 2002 - [[Niyaz Ahmad Khan]] * 2003 - [[Dinkar Kaykini|Pandit Dinkar Kaykini]] * 2004 - [[Shivkumar Sharma|Pandit Shivkumar Sharma]] - [[Santoor]] maestro. * 2005 - [[Malini Rajurkar]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist of the [[Gwalior gharana]] and acknowledged master of Tappa and Tarana. * 2006 - [[Sulochana Brahaspati]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist and exponent of the [[Rampur-Sahaswan gharana]]. * 2007 - [[Pandit Gokulotsav Maharaj]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist. * 2008 - [[Ghulam Mustafa Khan|Ustad Ghulam Mustafa Khan]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist and exponent of the [[Rampur-Sahaswan gharana]]. * 2009 - [[Ajay Pohankar]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist and exponent of the [[Kirana gharana]]. * 2010 - [[Savita Devi]] - [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] vocalist from the [[Benaras Gharana]]. * 2011 - [[Rajan and Sajan Mishra]] - Vocalist duo.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.business-standard.com/generalnews/news/rajansajan-mishra-to-get-national-tansen-samman/90913/ |title=Rajan and Sajan Mishra to get 'National Tansen Samman' |publisher=Business Standard |date=2012-12-09 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref> *2013 - [[Vishwa Mohan Bhatt]] - Hindustani classical music instrumentalist<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://soulsteer.com/Gwalior/mohan-veena-player-pandit-vishwa-mohan-bhatt-awarded-national-tansen-samman-2015 |title=Mohan Veena player Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt |publisher=SouLSteer |date=2015-12-24 |accessdate=2015-12-24}}</ref> *2014 - [[Prabhakar Karekar|Pandit Prabhakar Karekar]] - Indian Classical vocalist.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://soulsteer.com/tansen-samaroh-2014-prabhakar-karekar-awarded-with-national-tansen-samman/ |title=Tansen Samaroh 2014: Prabhakar Karekar awarded with National Tansen Samman |publisher=SouLSteer |date=2014-12-12 |accessdate=2014-12-12}}</ref> *2015 - [[Ajoy Chakrabarty]] - Indian Hindustani classical vocalist<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://soulsteer.com/Gwalior/hindustani-classical-vocalist-pandit-ajoy-chakrabarty-awarded-201415-national-tansen-samman/ |title=Hindustani classical vocalist Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty |publisher=SouLSteer |date=2015-12-25 |accessdate=2015-12-25}}</ref> *2015 - Pt. Laxman Krishnarao Pandit - Vocalist (Son of [[Krishnarao Shankar Pandit]]) *2016 - Pt. Dalchan Sharma - Pakhawaj Player *2017 - Pt. Ulhaas kashalkar- classical vocalist ( Jaipur gharana)
===2012===
Tansen Samaroh was organized jointly by Alauddin Khan Kala Evam Sangeet Academy and The Academy of the department of culture in [[Madhya Pradesh]] from 14–17 December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/state-editions/bhopal/111127-tansen-sangeet-samaroh-at-gaus-makbara.html |title=The Pioneer |publisher=Dailypioneer.com |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref>
'''2016'''
It is being organized from 16 to 20 December 2016<ref>http://tansensamaroh.com</ref>

This will be the final tour conducted by the band.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/lynyrd-skynyrd-plot-farewell-tour-w515880|title=Lynyrd Skynyrd Plot Farewell Tour|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-05-06}} It began May 4, 2018, at the [[Coral Sky Amphitheatre|Coral Sky Amphitheater]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]]{{Cite web|url=http://ultimateclassicrock.com/lynyrd-skynyrd-final-tour-videos-photos/|title=Lynyrd Skynyrd Kick Off Final Tour: Photos, Videos|website=Ultimate Classic Rock|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}} and will end January 8, 2019 after the Southern Rock Cruise concludes.{{Cite news|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/lynyrd-skynyrd-playing-hometown-show-with-kid-rock-jason-aldean/|title=Lynyrd Skynyrd playing hometown show with Kid Rock, Jason Aldean {{!}} The Music Universe|date=2018-04-19|work=The Music Universe|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}} The band will utilize a plethora of opening acts, including [[Bad Company]], [[Kid Rock]], and [[Hank Williams Jr.]],throughout the tour. == Setlist{{Cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/lynyrd-skynyrd/2018/midflorida-credit-union-amphitheatre-tampa-fl-3ec4d13.html|title=Lynyrd Skynyrd Setlist at MidFlorida Credit Union Amphitheatre, Tampa|website=setlist.fm|access-date=2018-05-06}} == The following setlist was taken from the May 5, 2018 performance at the [[MidFlorida Credit Union Amphitheatre|MidFlorida Credit Union Amphitheater]] in [[Tampa, Florida]] and may not be representative of all shows on the tour. # See template documentation for more info.--> | list_episodes = | executive_producer = [[Robert Deaton]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Allen Shapiro]]|[[Adam Anders]]|Mike Mahan|Mark Bracco| |David Arvesen|[[Robert Deaton]]}} | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = <!-- Reliable source required --> | company = {{ubl|[[Dick Clark Productions]]|Anders Media|Eye2Eye Media}} | distributor = | budget = | network =[[Fox network|Fox]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = <!-- The nation in which the series first aired, if different from country parameter --> | released = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | first_aired = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | last_aired = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = <!-- To be used only for remakes, spin-offs, and adaptations --> | website = | website_title = | production_website = | production_website_title = }}
'''''The Passion: New Orleans'''''<ref name="soundtrack" /> (also known as simply '''''The Passion'''''<ref name="billboard-replacing">{{cite web|title='The Passion' Stars Jencarlos Canela, Prince Royce & Chris Daughtry on Replacing Prayers With Pop Hits in Fox Biblical Musical|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/6977331/the-passion-prince-royce-chris-daughtry-interview|work=Billboard|date=March 10, 2016|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref>) is an American music television special that was broadcast by [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] on March 20, 2016. Based on the [[The Passion television franchise|Dutch franchise of the same name]] (which in turn, was adapted from a [[Manchester Passion|BBC special]]) and produced by [[Dick Clark Productions]] and Eye2Eye Media, it was a contemporary [[Passion Play|retelling]] of the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]] of [[Jesus Christ]] [[Jukebox musical|set to popular music]], through a mixture of live and pre-recorded segments broadcast from [[New Orleans]].<ref name="usatoday-review"/><ref name="deadline-ratings"/>
It starred musicians [[Jencarlos Canela]], [[Prince Royce]], [[Trisha Yearwood]], [[Chris Daughtry]], and [[Seal (singer)|Seal]]. [[Tyler Perry]] hosted and narrated the special, while [[Nischelle Turner]] served as a correspondent for the [[Way of the Cross|procession]] of a cross to [[Woldenberg Park (New Orleans)|Woldenberg Park]].
''The Passion'' received mixed reviews; critics noted that its [[secular]] soundtrack had weak context to the story, while the overall presentation of the special was compared to [[Super Bowl halftime show]]s and ''[[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve]]''. Particular praise was directed towards the performance of Seal, and how the presentation was received by the live audience. Tyler Perry's hosting received mixed reviews, with critics characterizing his narration as being restrained, and noting that the [[crucifixion of Jesus]] was presented solely through graphic dialogue. Shortcomings were also acknowledged in the special's format; despite an implied connection in promotion to the recent trend of live television productions of [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musicals (such as Fox's previous ''[[Grease: Live]]''), its format was dissimilar to that of a traditional [[stage musical]], and portions were pre-recorded. With a 4.3/7 [[Nielsen ratings|household rating]], the special was the second-highest-rated program of the night behind [[NBC]]'s ''[[Little Big Shots]]''.
==Production== [[File:The Passion door Cristo Padmos.jpg|thumb|left|As in the original Dutch versions of the special, the broadcast culminated with the procession of an illuminated [[Christian cross|cross]] to its main stage.<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/>]] In December 2015, Fox announced that [[Tyler Perry]] would host and narrate a television special based on the final hours of [[Jesus Christ]]'s life, broadcast live from [[New Orleans]] on March 20, 2016 ([[Palm Sunday]]), and produced by Eye2Eye Media and [[Dick Clark Productions]]. The special was formatted as a musical containing contemporary songs, and featured the [[Way of the Cross|procession]] of an illuminated cross from [[Champions Square]] (outside the [[Mercedes-Benz Superdome]]) to a stage at [[Woldenberg Park (New Orleans)|Woldenberg Park]].<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/><ref name="variety-tylerperry"/>
The story was portrayed using modernized imagery, and a script adapted from Bible scriptures by [[Peter Barsocchini]] of ''[[High School Musical]]'' fame, with the vetting of the [[American Bible Society]].<ref name="billboard-replacing"/> Producer Mark Bracco explained that ''The Passion'' would be "modern" and "inclusive", "whether you are a believer or wants to hear Trisha Yearwood sing a [[Whitney Houston]] song".<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/><ref name="billboard-yolanda"/> Perry emphasized the significance of using the city of New Orleans as the setting for the special; drawing parallels between [[Hurricane Katrina]] and the [[resurrection of Jesus]], he stated that New Orleans had "[[Effects of Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans|literally [risen] again from a liquid grave]]."<ref name="wp-review"/>
The special was an American adaptation of a [[The Passion (Netherlands)|Dutch television special of the same name]], which has been broadcast annually since 2011,<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/> and was, in turn, a localized version of the [[BBC]]'s 2006 special ''[[Manchester Passion]]''.<ref name="sheknows-7facts">{{cite web|last1=Nelson|first1=Carrie|title=7 Facts about Fox's next live musical, The Passion|url=http://www.sheknows.com/entertainment/articles/1111165/things-to-know-about-fox-next-live-musical-performance-the-passion|website=[[SheKnows]]|accessdate=17 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-manchester">{{cite news|title=Day that Jesus came to the Arndale Centre|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/apr/15/religion.arts|accessdate=12 February 2016|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Creator Jacco Doornbos, who conceptualized the special in 2007 after learning that only 25% of people in the Netherlands were aware of the story of Easter,<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/> described ''The Passion'' as having become the largest annual television event in the Netherlands. The 2015 edition was seen by approximately 3.57 million viewers, a 46% share.<ref name="metro-passion2015">{{cite news|title=TV Top 25: The Passion en dan heel lang niets|url=http://www.metronieuws.nl/showbizz/2015/04/tv-top-25-the-passion-en-dan-heel-lang-niets|accessdate=February 12, 2016|work=[[Metro (Dutch newspaper)|Metro]]|date=April 5, 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref><ref name="deadline-passion">{{cite web|title=Fox To Air ‘The Passion’ Live Musical About Jesus Hosted By Tyler Perry|url=http://deadline.com/2015/12/the-passion-live-musical-jesus-tyler-perry-fox-1201667399/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=12 February 2016}}</ref> As a live musical, ''The Passion'' also served as a follow-up to ''[[Grease: Live]]'', a live production of the 1971 musical ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'' that Fox had broadcast two months prior, as influenced by NBC's recent live productions of stage musicals.<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/>
[[File:Jencarlos Canela.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Jencarlos Canela]] in 2012]]
[[Adam Anders]], who previously worked on fellow Fox series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', served as executive producer and music director for ''The Passion''. He elaborated that the goal of the special's soundtrack was to present well-known songs "in a completely new context". [[Chris Daughtry]], an ''[[American Idol]]'' alumnus who was cast as [[Judas]], stated that his songs—[[Imagine Dragons]]' "[[Demons (Imagine Dragons song)|Demons]]" (which was performed as a duet with Jesus—played by [[Jencarlos Canela]], during [[Judas Iscariot#Betrayal of Jesus|Judas's betrayal]]) and [[Evanescence]]'s "[[Bring Me to Life]]", would be "very different interpretations" of the original tracks.<ref name="billboard-replacing"/><ref name="variety-tylerperry">{{cite web|title=TV Roundup: Tyler Perry to Host Easter Event ‘The Passion’ on Fox|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/tyler-perry-the-passion-fox-musical-1201662252/|website=Variety|accessdate=12 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="thr-passionperry"/><ref name="thr-passionperry"/><ref name="tvline-passion">{{cite web|title=Fox Staging The Passion, Live: How Trisha Yearwood, Imagine Dragons and NOLA Will Tell Jesus' Story|url=http://tvline.com/2016/01/15/fox-the-passion-live-musical-imagine-dragons-new-orleans/|website=TV Line|accessdate=12 February 2016}}</ref> Anders felt that the project fit well with Fox due to the network's history with music-based series, such as ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' (a series which Anders also worked on)<ref name="billboard-replacing"/> and ''[[Empire (2015 TV series)|Empire]]''.<ref name="deadline-perrypassion"/> Anders believed that the "power" of the presentation and its use of popular music helped influence the popularity of ''The Passion'' in the Netherlands—where, according to a recent survey, more people practiced [[atheism]] or agnosticism combined than [[theism]].<ref name="nltimes-atheists">{{cite web|title=More Atheists than Believers, but 60% on the fence|url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2015/01/16/atheists-believers-60-pct-fence/|website=NLTimes|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="trouw.nl">{{cite news|last1=van Beek|first1=Marije|title=Ongelovigen halen de gelovigen in|url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/5091/Religie/article/detail/3830831/2015/01/16/Ongelovigen-halen-de-gelovigen-in.dhtml|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=Dossier Relige|publisher=der Verdieping Trouw|date=16 January 2015}}</ref> As such, Anders felt that the concept could be "huge" in the U.S. due to the level of religious practice in the country.<ref name="billboard-replacing"/> He stressed that the integrity of the story would be maintained, remarking that "I'm a pastor's kid, and I have a cheese alarm that goes off easily. I knew I couldn't have the disciples breakdancing."<ref name="billboard-replacing"/>
The concept of ''The Passion'' was met with skepticism; Anders remarked that he had difficulty convincing musicians to allow use of their songs because the concept of ''The Passion'' was difficult to explain, while Chris Daughtry and Prince Royce were initially hesitant towards the concept of participating in an overtly religious production.<ref name="billboard-replacing"/> Daughtry did remark that he enjoyed the idea of playing an antagionist, and felt that Judas was a "very human" and "very relatable" character.<ref name="billboard-replacing"/><ref name="ew-daughtry">{{cite web|title=See Chris Daughtry rehearse as Judas for Fox's The Passion musical — exclusive first look|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/07/chris-daughtry-passion-judas-video|website=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref> [[Prince Royce]], who was cast as [[Saint Peter]], similarly promised that he would take his role seriously and not act as "the normal Prince Royce who takes his shirt off and gets the girls screaming".<ref name="billboard-replacing"/> Tyler Perry, who practices Christianity,<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael Kress |url=http://www.beliefnet.com/Entertainment/TV/Tyler-Perrys-House-Of-Payne/Diary-Of-A-Faithful-Black-Man.aspx |title=Interview with Michael Kress: Tyler Perry, Diary of a Mad Black Woman, "Meet the Browns" Madea's Family Reunion, Daddy's Little Girls |publisher=Beliefnet.com |date= |accessdate=November 13, 2011}}</ref> was enthusiastic about being involved in such an event occurring in his hometown, and joked that contributing to a project that he did not [[Tyler Perry#Filmography|personally create]] was like a "vacation".<ref name="thr-passionperry">{{cite web|title=Tyler Perry Talks Appeal and Challenges of Fox's Live Jesus Musical|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tyler-perry-talks-appeal-challenges-856312|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=12 February 2016}}</ref> He felt that the modern setting and contemporary music would make the story more accessible to a general audience.<ref name="deadline-perrypassion">{{cite web|title=Fox’s ‘The Passion’ Brings Biblical Story "Back To The Public Space – TCA|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/trisha-yearwood-mary-the-passion-jesus-fox-tcs-1201683986/|website=Deadline|accessdate=12 February 2016}}</ref>
Celebrity chef [[Carla Hall]] made a cameo appearance staffing a [[food truck]] that Jesus used to cater the [[Last Supper]],<ref name="atlantic-passion" /> while the [[Preservation Hall Jazz Band]] also appeared for a performance of "[[When the Saints Go Marching In]]".<ref name="wp-review"/> [[Nischelle Turner]] served as a co-host, primarily serving as a reporter along the procession route to Woldenberg Park.<ref name="usatoday-review" />

==Broadcast== ''The Passion'' was broadcast by Fox on March 20, 2016; the telecast was preceded by the premiere of an ''[[Ice Age (franchise)|Ice Age]]'' Easter special, ''[[Ice Age: The Great Egg-Scapade|The Great Egg-Scapade]]''.<ref name="usatoday-iceage">{{cite news|title=TV tonight: 'Ice Age' Easter special, 'The Passion'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/columnist/criticscorner/2016/03/20/march-20-critics-corner/81595222/|accessdate=20 March 2016|work=USA Today}}</ref> In Canada, ''The Passion'' aired on [[Omni Television]] stations in simulcast with Fox.<ref name="rogers-highlightsmar20">{{cite web|title=City Prime-time Programming Highlights: Monday, Mar. 14 to Sunday, Mar. 20|url=http://www.rogersmediatv.ca/pr_detail.php?id=1323|publisher=Rogers Media|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> The special received a 4.3/7 household rating, putting it behind NBC's ''[[Little Big Shots]]'' as the second-highest rated show of the night.<ref name="deadline-ratings">{{cite web|title=‘The Passion’ Ratings & Tyler Perry Down Sharply From ‘Grease Live’ For Fox|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/the-passion-ratings-tyler-perry-fox-trisha-yearwood-seal-daughtry-grease-live-fox-1201723502/|website=Deadline|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> [[Netflix]] acquired international digital rights to ''The Passion'' outside of the United States and Netherlands; it was made available for streaming beginning on March 25, 2016.<ref name="deadline-netflix">{{cite web|title=Netflix Picks Up ‘The Passion’ Live Musical Special For Global Distribution|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/the-passion-live-musical-netflix-global-distribution-1201722840/|website=Deadline|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref>
